title: Europe's New Jobs Lack Old Guarantees-Stoking Workers' Discontent
summary: Resume Subscription. Europe's job market is booming. So why are so many workers so angry?

title: Hoard of Jewels Stolen in German Museum Heist
summary: Nearly 100 pieces of 18th-century jewelry were taken from Dresden's Grünes Gewölbe, authorities said. BERLIN-German police are investigating what experts are calling one of the most devastating jewelry heists in history after nearly a hundred pieces of 18th-century jewelry were stolen from one of Europe's most renowned treasure collections early Monday.

title: Judge Rejects White House Claims of Immunity for Aides
summary: Decision could clear path for administration officials to appear before Congress in impeachment inquiry. WASHINGTON-A federal judge has ruled that close presidential advisers aren't immune from being forced to testify in congressional inquiries in an opinion that could eventually clear the way for numerous administration officials to be summoned as part of the impeachment investigation of President Trump.

title: Uber Loses License in London
summary: Regulator cites vulnerabilities in Uber's app and passenger safety for its decision. LONDON- Uber Technologies Inc. lost its license to operate in London, one of its most important markets, after regulators found widespread instances of unauthorized drivers using the ride-hailing app to pick up customers.

title: EBay to Sell StubHub in Deal to Create Global Tickets Giant
summary: Geneva-based Viagogo to acquire bigger rival for $4 billion as the live-events industry surges. EBay Inc. said it agreed to sell its StubHub business to Geneva-based Viagogo Entertainment Inc. for $4.05 billion, a deal that would create a global ticketing giant in the booming live-events business.

title: Trump, Democrats Spar Over North American Trade Deal
summary: Pelosi says she awaits word from Trump administration after president blames her for delay. WASHINGTON-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, facing criticism from Republicans for not embracing a renegotiated trade agreement with Canada and Mexico, said Monday she is awaiting final written commitments from the Trump administration.

title: Corporate Executives Try to Assess Potential Impact of Suggested Tax Rules Amid Lack of Detail
summary: Companies are studying suggestions by the OECD that would mark a departure from current international tax rules, but details are murky. Corporate tax chiefs are trying to assess the potential implications of a proposal for a new global tax system for consumer-facing businesses, an effort that is being complicated by what some companies describe as a lack of critical details.

title: AIG to Sell Vast Majority of Fortitude Stake to Carlyle, T&D
summary: AIG said it would receive a $500 million distribution from Fortitude. American International Group Inc. said it would sell the vast majority of its stake in Fortitude Group Holdings LLC to the Carlyle Group LP and Japanese insurance firm T&D Holdings Inc. for roughly $1.8 billion, as the insurer works on paring down its exposure to lines of business it no longer sells.

title: Samsung Shipbuilder Settles Petrobras Bribery Charges for $75 Million
summary: Samsung Heavy Industries funneled bribes through an intermediary to Brazil's state-controlled energy company, prosecutors said. A shipbuilding subsidiary of South Korea's Samsung Group agreed to pay $75 million to settle bribery charges stemming from a corruption scheme involving Brazil's state-controlled energy company.

title: Apple Settles Allegations of U.S. Sanctions Violations
summary: The tech giant allegedly dealt with a blacklisted entity for more than two years, the Treasury Department said. Apple Inc. has agreed to pay about $467,000 to settle allegations it violated U.S. sanctions by dealing with a blacklisted entity for more than two years, the Treasury Department said Monday.

title: SEC Moves to Overhaul Rules on Mutual Funds' Use of Derivatives
summary: If enacted, the proposed rules would replace a patchwork of guidelines issued over recent decades. WASHINGTON-The Securities and Exchange Commission is taking another stab at regulating the use of derivatives by investment funds, after an attempt by the Obama administration to establish stricter rules was shelved amid industry opposition.

title: Trump Ordered That Gallagher Remain a Navy SEAL, Pentagon Chief Says
summary: President's order came in a Sunday phone call to Mark Esper. WASHINGTON-President Trump ordered U.S. defense officials to allow a Navy SEAL to remain a member of the elite group, Defense Secretary Mark Esper said Monday, a move that ended a controversy that had pit military commanders against the White House and cost the Navy secretary his post.

title: Tiffany Accepts a Sparklier Proposal
summary: After raising its offer to $16.2 billion, the luxury giant behind Louis Vuitton will need time to polish the U.S. jeweler. If an engagement ring should cost three months of a suitor's salary, LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton is paying slightly over the odds for Tiffany & Co. But investors are feeling indulgent toward a stock that has risen 66% this year.

title: Trump and the SEALs
summary: Senior officers worry about tolerance for a culture of ill-discipline.. President Trump has done much to lift military morale with his rhetorical and financial support after the Obama years of indifference. So it's troubling to see the Commander in Chief get crosswise with the officer corps over what the military calls "good order and discipline."

title: Thanksgiving at the Supreme Court
summary: Two notable opinions on speech and the non-delegation doctrine.. The Supreme Court didn't issue a landmark decision Monday, but it did shoot off a couple of flares. Notably, the Court rebuked the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals for again flouting its precedents while Justice Brett Kavanaugh put a stake down on the Constitution's non-delegation doctrine.

title: Making Capitalism Great Again?
summary: Marco Rubio's ideas for fixing our free-market system have a familiar ring.. Marco Rubio thumps for "common good capitalism." Elizabeth Warren speaks of "making markets work for people." While their prescriptions differ, they share the conviction that capitalism is in crisis and must be "fixed" if it is again to serve the American people.

title: Supreme Court Suspends House Subpoena Seeking Trump's Financial Information
summary: High court now likely to consider case that strikes at heart of the U.S. Constitution. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court granted President Trump's emergency request to suspend enforcement of a congressional subpoena seeking his financial records from his accounting firm, a move that could keep the documents from House Democrats for months-if they see them at all.

title: The Fighting Continues in Northern Syria
summary: The Kurds vow to defend themselves-alone if necessary-against Syria, Turkey and Russia.. Tal Tamr, Syria

title: China Is Europe's Problem Too
summary: Only the trans-Atlantic alliance can counter Beijing's moves in the Pacific.. What will the trans-Atlantic alliance look like in a world focused on the Indo-Pacific? That, more than President Trump's unpredictable diplomacy, is the question that haunts Europe. During the Cold War, protecting Europe from Soviet aggression was Washington's highest foreign-policy priority. That didn't only mean that the U.S. put troops in Europe. Washington took European opinions seriously, engaged with Europeans, cut deals with them and was willing to make concessions to preserve alliance unity.

title: There's No Safe Space for Ideas on Campus 'Animal Farms'
summary: Zealous student activists find ways to punish those who make them think uncomfortable thoughts.. Most Americans know that higher education has for several decades been in the grip of a deeply intolerant, fanatical and uncompromising strain of progressive activism. Students and sometimes even faculty members regularly chase heterodox speakers off campus, demand complete fealty from terrified campus bureaucracies, and denounce and destroy each other over the slightest and most inconsequential ideological deviations. The environment isn't unlike George Orwell's "Animal Farm," a place where "no one dared speak his mind, when fierce, growling dogs roamed everywhere, and when you had to watch your comrades torn to pieces after confessing to shocking crimes."

title: PG&E Refuses to Get Burned
summary: Under the utility's incentive structure, blackouts make sense.. Stanford, Calif.

title: I Should Never Have Gotten Involved With the MOB
summary: Owning a medical office building proved too much to handle for this simple residential landlord.. Writer Martin Amis, the son of novelist Kingsley Amis, said it is somewhat disreputable to be in the same business as your father. "Being a hereditary novelist is a freaky thing, and people do find it a bit creepy," Martin said.

title: 'The Imperiled Ocean' Review: A Dive Into the Deep
summary: A series of "human stories" from the high seas that together convey the immensity and influence of the ocean ecosystem.. Laura Trethewey's "The Imperiled Ocean: Human Stories From a Changing Sea" is a platypus of a book, composed of odd and mismatched parts, more a collection of essays than not, an enterprise that began, writes the author, "with a simple question: what do people want from the ocean?" You might think that each of the book's seven radically different chapters would provide its own direct answer. But it's not that simple in narratives where sometimes the ocean, per se, isn't even present.

title: Notable & Quotable: John Simon
summary: 'Criticism should also be comprehensible, which is to say not written by Frenchmen with esoteric theories and befuddling jargon.'. John Simon, who died Sunday at 94, writing in the New Criterion, November 2018:

title: Proxy Advisers Should Serve the Stockholders
summary: A clear legal obligation to first represent the interests of stockholders would help keep the proxy advisory firms' focus where it belongs.. Carl Icahn is an activist investor with a penchant for confronting incompetent, misguided or complacent corporate management, but he is wrong to oppose the Securities and Exchange Commission's proposed new rules for proxy advisory firms ("Let Proxy Advisers Do Their Work," op-ed, Nov. 19).

title: It Isn't Racist to Honor the Military's Dead
summary: The firing of Canadian hockey commentator Don Cherry for his "discriminatory" and "offensive" comments is another example of what's wrong with our Western society.. Regarding Elliot Kaufman's "Political Correctness Claims a Tough Guy" (op-ed, Nov. 13): The firing of Canadian hockey commentator Don Cherry for his "discriminatory" and "offensive" comments is a another example of what's wrong with our Western society. Patriotism no longer counts. He was suggesting immigrants should respect and honor the men and women who serve and those who died for the country in which they now live. Don't so many people immigrate to have this freedom? Suggesting they buy and wear poppies is innocent and shows honor to the veterans who sacrificed for the freedom today's immigrants enjoy.

title: Look Out Below for Falling School Standards
summary: Madison's spending per student is the highest relative to comparably sized districts in Wisconsin, but the city has one of the worst black-white achievement gaps in the state and perhaps the country.. Regarding C.J. Szafir and Cori Petersen's "Beware Warren's 'Madisonian' Plan for Public Education" (Cross Country, Nov. 16): Sen. Elizabeth Warren's plan for K-12 education, if she wins the White House, is to "increase federal funding for public schools by $800 billion . . . strengthen teachers unions, and halt the growth of public charter schools." Madison's spending per student is the highest relative to comparably sized districts in Wisconsin, but the city has one of the worst black-white achievement gaps in the state and perhaps the country. Black students in Madison also are far more likely than whites to attend dangerous schools.

title: For Millennia, Philosophy Underperformed Physics
summary: Knowledge in philosophy hasn't progressed: The original questions haven't been answered.. Nicholas Stang's review of A.C. Grayling's "The History of Philosophy" (Books, Nov. 16) is one more example of navel gazing, or omphaloskepsis, by a philosopher. A history of philosophy records the ideas of Thales, Socrates, Hegel and others, but so does a textbook of philosophy. In contrast, a textbook of physics is different from a history of physics because physics has advanced from Aristotle to Galileo to Newton to Einstein and on. Current knowledge in physics is quite different from previous knowledge. But a textbook of philosophy is written as a history of philosophy because knowledge in philosophy hasn't progressed: The original questions haven't been answered.

title: Hurting People You Help, But for Their Own Good
summary: Concerns that Democratic proposals would impair economic growth and hurt the middle class surely must apply to other elements of the emerging Democratic wish list.. While I agree with Fred Hatfield ("Sanders's Tax Would Hit Small Investors," op-ed, Nov. 18) about the negatives of Bernie Sanders's financial transaction tax, why stop there with the critique of Democratic Party economic proposals? Concerns that Democratic proposals would impair economic growth and hurt the middle class surely must apply to other elements of the emerging Democratic wish list as well, including the Green New Deal, Medicare for All, etc. In my view, virtually the entire menu of Democratic economic proposals is antigrowth, and the financial transaction tax seems to be relatively small potatoes compared with some of the other ideas being discussed.

title: New York, MTA Sued Over Tough Contracting Rules
summary: Parent companies, subsidiaries and affiliates face possible debarment, which can apply retroactively, if there are delays and cost overruns. A group representing thousands of contractors sued New York state and the state-controlled Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Monday over rules that punish firms for delays and cost overruns on infrastructure projects.

title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise's Revenue Drops Across Segments
summary: Company maintains profit targets for the year, points to improved gross margin. Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co. reported a larger-than-expected revenue decline in the latest period but said it still expects to return to revenue growth this year, when adjusted for currency fluctuations.

title: Westpac Banking CEO and Chairman Depart
summary: CEO Brian Hartzer and Chairman Lindsay Maxsted are set to exit as Australian bank seeks to steady itself. MELBOURNE, Australia- Westpac Banking Corp.'s chief executive and chairman are stepping down as Australia's second-largest bank seeks to steady itself after being accused of breaching anti-money-laundering finance laws millions of times.

title: Woman Who Trespassed at Mar-a-Lago Gets Eight-Month Sentence
summary: Yujing Zhang was carrying two passports, four cellphones and other electronics. A Chinese woman was sentenced to eight months in prison on Monday after being convicted in September on charges unlawfully entering President Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida.

title: New York State Panel Approves Public Campaign Finance System
summary: Donation limits to statewide candidates will be cut by more than half, minor parties will need more signatures to get on ballot. The New York State Public Campaign Finance Reform Commission voted Monday to establish a statewide system that matches small political donations with taxpayer funds and makes it more difficult for minor parties to appear on the ballot.

title: Their Inner Glow Restored
summary: With 4K transfers, classic films look as we dream they did at their premieres.

title: Bank Branch Closings Weigh on Rural Communities, Fed Finds
summary: Poorer residents and large minority populations are reported to be particularly hard hit. WASHINGTON-A majority of U.S. counties lost bank branches in recent years, and rural communities with poorer residents or large minority populations have been particularly hard hit, according to new Federal Reserve research.

summary: At the Joyce Theater in New York, Spain's folkloric dance tradition is stripped down to its essence. New York

summary: Resume Subscription. To break the ice at Notre Dame pep rallies, Samuel Jackson II opens by saying, "You're probably wondering why this leprechaun looks a bit different. Yes, I know I'm tall."

title: Schiff Says Impeachment Report Could Come Next Week
summary: Investigators compile evidence for lawmakers to consider ahead of full chamber vote to impeach Trump. WASHINGTON-House investigators could turn over a report laying out the evidence for impeaching President Trump to the House Judiciary Committee as early as next week, setting the stage for the House to vote on the matter before the end of the year.

title: Former Outcome Health Executives Charged in Alleged $1 Billion Fraud
summary: U.S. prosecutors say company's previous leadership sought to defraud customers, investors; indicted executives deny allegations. Federal prosecutors charged former executives of Outcome Health with allegedly falsifying data in a nearly $1 billion scheme to defraud the company's clients and investors, including Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Alphabet Inc. and an investment firm founded by Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker.

title: Argentine Court Convicts Two Catholic Priests of Sexual Abuse
summary: Verdict in a case that horrified the country raised questions about how Pope Francis responded to the crimes. An Argentine court found two Catholic priests guilty of sexually abusing children at a school for the deaf, in a case that horrified the country and raised questions about how Pope Francis, an Argentine native, responded to the crimes.

title: Small Caps Are Trading at the Highest Levels of 2019
summary: Monday's rally was largely driven by deal activity, improving sentiment on trade, and strength in the financial and biotech sectors. The Russell 2000 hit a new 52-week high-a novelty for the small-cap stock index, which has lagged, as other major U.S. stock indexes have notched a string of recent records.

title: New Drugs Emerge to Treat Sickle Cell Disease
summary: The FDA approved Oxbryta, a once-daily pill from Global Blood Therapeutics. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved a new drug for sickle cell disease Monday, adding to a new wave of treatments that promise relief from the life-threatening blood disorder that largely afflicts African-Americans.

title: S&P 500 Ends One Streak but Continues to Climb
summary: This month's rally has been driven in part by economically sensitive companies, implying more confidence about the economy's health. The S&P 500 snapped a six-week winning streak Friday, but some analysts played down the significance of the broken record and suggested the benchmark stock index has more room to run.

title: Stocks Start to Diverge After Months of Trading in Tandem
summary: Easing market tensions have allowed investors to refocus on company fundamentals, opening a window for stock picking. Conditions for stock picking are improving.

title: Why eBay Is Stuck in the Cheap Seats
summary: Selling StubHub lands a nice return, but leaves e-commerce business more exposed to unflattering Amazon comparisons. For eBay , selling StubHub may prove to be the easy part.

title: Tech Shares Power U.S. Stocks Higher
summary: Investors cheer step by China to boost intellectual property rights, a lingering issue in the U.S.-China trade fight. U.S. stocks rose to records at the start of a holiday-shortened week, buoyed by a rally in shares of technology companies.

title: Activist Investor Takes Stake in CVS
summary: Starboard Value has held amicable talks with health-care giant. Activist investor Starboard Value LP has taken a stake in CVS Health Corp. and held talks with the drugstore-and-insurance giant's management, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: GE Picks Outsider From Maersk as New Finance Chief
summary: Carolina Dybeck Happe will join conglomerate as it tries to turn around its business after two difficult years. General Electric Co. said it hired an executive at A.P. Moeller-Maersk A/S as its next chief financial officer, tapping another outsider to help the American conglomerate turn around its operations.

title: Inside LVMH, Tiffany to Fall Under Billionaire's Exacting Eye
summary: Billionaire is readying playbook used to build some of the world's most successful luxury brands. PARIS- Tiffany & Co.'s underperforming operations are about to get an overhaul from one of the world's most exacting executives, French billionaire Bernard Arnault.

title: Iranians Hold Pro-Establishment Rallies, Blaming U.S. for Unrest
summary: Rallies follow crackdown on nationwide protests that erupted this month over a sudden hike in gasoline prices. Thousands of Iranians staged pro-establishment rallies in Tehran and other cities in a show of support after the country's leaders suppressed nationwide protests that erupted this month over a sudden hike in gasoline prices.

title: Federal Subpoenas Seek Information on Giuliani's Consulting Business
summary: Subpoenas are issued for information on Giuliani's associates, Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman. Subpoenas issued to people with ties to President Trump's personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, indicate a broad federal investigation into possible money laundering, obstruction of justice and campaign-finance violations and show that prosecutors are probing Mr. Giuliani's consulting businesses and other sources of income, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Emerging Fashion Brands Depended on Barneys. Now What?
summary: The sophisticated department store gave many emerging fashion designers a significant boost. Now that it's gone, young brands are warily preparing for a different future. WHEN THE ONCE-MIGHTY fashion retailer Barneys New York declared bankruptcy in August, court documents revealed that some of the industry's most vaunted labels were among its biggest creditors. The store owed roughly $2.7 million to Celine, $2.2 million to Saint Laurent, $2.1 million to Balenciaga and $1.9 million to Givenchy in outstanding payments for merchandise. Earlier this month, a bankruptcy judge approved the sale of the store's intellectual property to the New York-based fashion conglomerate Authentic Brands Group (ABG). B. Riley Financial purchased the remaining Barneys inventory and almost immediately began liquidating the store's remaining stock. Discounts started at 5% and have steadily inched upward.

title: Fresh Trade Optimism Hits Gold
summary: Hopes for U.S.-China deal brighten investors' outlook for global growth in 2020. Monday reports that the U.S. and China are closing in on an initial trade accord represent the latest blow to gold's 2019 rally, another threat to investors who had piled into bullion earlier in the year.

title: Swedish Executive Brings Global Experience, Outsider's Perspective to GE Finance Role
summary: Carolina Dybeck Happe was instrumental in cutting costs as Maersk shifted its focus-a background that may be useful as GE seeks to reinvent itself. Swedish finance executive Carolina Dybeck Happe, who on Monday was named as General Electric Co. 's incoming finance chief, is relatively unknown to U.S. investors.

title: With Help From Ken Burns, Hampshire College Clears Key Hurdle
summary: Liberal-arts school keeps accreditation in fight for survival. Hampshire College, one of many small liberal arts schools in the U.S. trying to stay afloat while competing for a dwindling supply of high-school graduates, has cleared a key hurdle with its regional accreditor.

title: Trump Hails Military Dog Injured in Baghdadi Raid
summary: Canine injured in Syria is introduced to reporters outside the White House. WASHINGTON-President Trump honored the military canine injured in the raid that killed Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, hailing the Belgian Malinois as "incredible."

title: Pac-12 Looks Set to Miss the College Football Playoff Party
summary: After Oregon's loss to Arizona State, Utah is the conference's lone one-loss team. But the Utes' résumé is now weakened due to the Ducks' defeat.. Heading into last weekend, the Pac-12 Conference was one of the biggest surprises of the college football season. Two of its teams somehow found themselves on the cusp of cracking the top four of the College Football Playoff rankings, with Oregon ranked sixth and Utah seventh.

title: McDonald's to Pay $26 Million in Wage Suit
summary: Class-action lawsuit from 2013 involved claims made by restaurant workers in California. McDonald's Corp. agreed to pay $26 million to settle a long-running labor dispute over allegations that the fast-food giant underpaid staff in certain California restaurants.

summary: Thanksgiving stock market performance has become spotty, but the Santa Claus Rally remains a good bet. Thanksgiving just isn't as good as it used to be.

title: Retired Admiral, Lobbyist Braithwaite Is Tapped to Head Navy
summary: Current ambassador to Norway is tapped by Trump after ouster of Richard Spencer. President Trump has chosen a retired Navy admiral who also has worked as a health-care lobbyist to assume the post of Navy secretary following the ouster of Richard Spencer on Sunday.

title: Bloomberg's New Trump Rules
summary: Only one presidential candidate will be subject to the media outlet's investigative journalism.. Conservatives often suspect-and not without reason-that many large media outlets are biased against their favorite political candidates. But now at least one media empire is explicitly promising a double standard in its coverage of the presidential primary campaign. Until the Democrats settle on a nominee, only one 2020 contender will be subject to the news organization's most rigorous scrutiny. Readers can probably guess his name.

title: Schwab-Ameritrade Tie-Up Requires Patience
summary: Combining the two online brokers is good for investors, but the benefits won't be fully realized for years. For online brokerage investors, it is about the destination, not the journey.

title: In Venice, a Struggle to Rescue Damaged Art and Architecture
summary: Resume Subscription. Venice is on a restoration mission after a flood inundated the city, causing widespread damage to its priceless cultural heritage.

title: Fed Officials Close to Filling Two Top Markets Jobs
summary: New York Federal Reserve in final stages of finding replacements for roles open since June. Top Federal Reserve officials are in the final stages of a search to fill two top staff jobs overseeing its financial markets operations, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Saudi Arabia Arrests Opponents Despite Sensitivity Amid IPO Push
summary: At least nine people are held by Saudi authorities, including businessmen and journalists. Saudi authorities have arrested several high-profile people in recent days, extending an effort to sideline Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's perceived opponents, despite a push to repair the kingdom's international image to attract investment.

title: National Grid Ends Moratorium on New Hookups in New York
summary: The utility will provide service for two years as it examines long-term solutions to growing energy demands. National Grid PLC will resume connecting new natural-gas customers in Queens, Brooklyn and Long Island after reaching a deal with New York that ends a monthslong moratorium.

title: New York City Lawyers and Police Prepare for Evidence Changes
summary: New pretrial laws will give defendants earlier access to evidence. New York City officials will spend nearly $75 million to help police and attorneys comply with sweeping new laws set to begin in New York state next year that are intended to ensure fair hearings for criminal defendants.

title: Executive Behind 'Survivor' and 'The Amazing Race' Sues CBS Alleging Wrongful Termination
summary: Ghen Maynard contends CBS is pushing him out as part of purge of older executives, and that his ethnicity played a role. Ghen Maynard, a veteran CBS Corp. programming executive who helped shepherd some of the biggest TV shows of the past two decades, including "Survivor," claims he is being forced out of his job because of his race and age and accused the company of conducting a "sham" bias investigation into him.

title: Harvard-Yale Halftime Protest Results in Charges for 42
summary: Demonstrators occupying midfield urged action on climate change, other issues. NEW HAVEN, Conn.-Officials say 42 people were charged with disorderly conduct after a protest interrupted a Saturday football game between rivals Harvard and Yale.

summary: Resume Subscription. In late 2016, a group of plaintiffs' lawyers took the stage at the year's largest gathering of their colleagues to talk up a promising new target.

summary: Economy widely expected to show little or no growth in all of 2019. MEXICO CITY-Mexico's economic activity was flat in the third quarter following three quarters of negative output, putting the economy on track for its worst yearly performance in a decade.

summary: These real-estate agents recall getting locked out-and locked in-during a pair of home showings.

title: CMA CGM to Raise $2 Billion to Finance Logistics Buyout
summary: French shipping giant will sell port assets to a joint venture with China Merchants to back its acquisition of Ceva Logistics. France's CMA CGM SA plans to raise around $2 billion by the middle of next year through a series of deals in its shipping operations to finance the recent acquisition of Ceva Logistics.

title: Here's Where Bloomberg Stands in 2020 Field
summary: The billionaire has staked out positions on several high-profile issues that matter to business. Editor's note: This is an excerpt from our new newsletter, "2020 Election+Business," a weekly dive into the intersection of business, finance and the 2020 election. You can sign up here.

title: Investment Advisers Fear Losing Out in Schwab-TD Ameritrade Deal
summary: Takeover plan vexes those who park their clients' money with big online brokerages. Wall Street has roared its approval for Charles Schwab Corp.'s plan to buy TD Ameritrade Holding Corp. , but the proposed deal isn't sitting well with one key group: the financial advisers who park their clients' money with the big online brokerages.

summary: Russian leader racks up wins, from discord in the West to shifting power in the Mideast. Vladimir Putin has had a good year, and it just keeps getting better. He now is collecting his winnings on multiple fronts.

title: Democratic Hopefuls Face Growing Scrutiny Over Health Plans
summary: Industry groups and political opponents on both sides seize on alternatives to Medicare for All. With public support for Medicare for All slipping, opponents are ramping up attacks on more moderate alternatives from former Vice President Joe Biden and South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg.

title: Fox Sells Out of Super Bowl Ad Time Months Ahead of Event
summary: Thirty seconds of ad time sold for as much at $5.6 million, topping last year's $5.3 million. Fox Corp. said commercial time during Super Bowl LIV is sold out, as a strong economy and marketers' appetite for live sports fueled better-than-expected demand.

title: Socialist Group Works to Pull U.K. Labour Party Leftward Before Vote
summary: Resume Subscription. LONDON-One recent evening, Holly Rigby stood in front of a whiteboard with the words "Anger Action Hope" written on it, instructing volunteers how to sell Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn's socialist vision for Britain in two minutes.

summary: As Black Friday's hold on the season has loosened, shopping patterns diverge by age.. Black Friday is coming up: Are you an ecoshopper, an online convert or a retro doorbuster?

title: Newly Elected Councilors Step Up Challenge to Hong Kong Leaders, Beijing
summary: Energized by landslide win against pro-China candidates, pro-democracy victors repeat calls for political solution to city's unrest. HONG KONG-A day after Hong Kong residents voted in record numbers to back the city's pro-democracy movement, newly elected local leaders took to an embattled university campus to support protesters still trapped inside, and stepped up calls for a political solution to the unrest.

title: Carly Simon: How Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Changed My Life
summary: The singer and writer discusses her new book, Touched by the Sun: My Friendship with Jackie, about her odd-couple friendship with Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. Carly Simon has a voice that fits the Shakespearean ideal: "ever soft, gentle, and low." The 74-year-old singer and writer has a mind that wanders before suddenly homing in on a detail with the perfectly chosen phrase or word. As in her new book, Touched by the Sun: My Friendship with Jackie, about her unlikely camaraderie with Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, she is chronically honest about her feelings and her experiences.

summary: China was losing global export market share before the trade war. China-U.S. tensions may not matter for global trade as much as investors seem to think.

summary: Emirates swapped 24 orders for Boeing's state-of-the-art 777X for smaller planes, underscoring the growing weakness in demand for high-capacity jets. Demand for large planes is slackening at a very inconvenient time for Boeing .

title: Charles Schwab to Buy TD Ameritrade for $26 Billion

title: Pope Offers Nuclear-Power Caution After Meeting With Victims of 2011 Japan Disaster
summary: 'Important decisions will have to be made about the use of natural resources, and future energy sources in particular,' Pope Francis said. TOKYO-Pope Francis warned about the potential damage to society from technology such as nuclear power after meeting victims of Japan's 2011 nuclear disaster.

title: CFOs Wonder if Cadillac Tax Will Ever Take Effect
summary: Levy on high-cost health coverage, scheduled to go into effect in 2022, could initially affect more than one-fifth of U.S. companies. The uncertainty of a tax on pricey health coverage hangs over finance chiefs as they aim to cut costs and prepare for the levy despite its possible repeal.

title: Car Makers Wager on Bigger Screens to Lure Buyers
summary: The larger displays spark questions about whether they help or hinder efforts to curb distracted driving. When it comes to the media display in your car, auto makers are betting size does matter.

title: LVMH Agrees to Acquire Tiffany in $16.2 Billion Deal
summary: Takeover would expand European giant's jewelry business and double down on Chinese buyers. The European luxury conglomerate behind Louis Vuitton and Bulgari is taking over Tiffany & Co. in a more than $16 billion gamble that it can restore shine to the famed jeweler.

title: Hong Kong's New Political Stars Wallop Beijing's Loyal Foot Soldiers
summary: In North Point, packed with mainland Chinese immigrants loyal to Beijing, a 22-year-old fresh college graduate thrashes longtime politician and television presenter. HONG KONG-The rising tide of young political opposition here was on full view in the dense residential neighborhood of North Point, packed with mainland Chinese immigrants loyal to Beijing, where incumbent Frankie Lo found himself in a rare fight to retain his seat on the local district council.

title: Bitcoin Drops Below $7,000 as China Euphoria Fades
summary: Regulators reaffirm tough stance on companies involved in cryptocurrency trading and fundraising. When Chinese leader Xi Jinping touted blockchain technology in October, the price of bitcoin surged, searches for "blockchain" on one of China's biggest search engines soared and shares of related companies jumped.

title: Older IT Workers Left Out Despite Tech Talent Shortage
summary: U.S. tech sector skews younger than the workforce as a whole, with the largest gap among employees 35 to 44. Older information-technology professionals are being passed over by employers, even as IT job openings soar to record highs and employers say recruiting tech talent is a challenge.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Alstom Unit Ordered to Pay $21 Million in Tunisia Corruption Case
summary: The fine brings to an end a decade-long corruption case against subsidiaries of the French transportation company. A British subsidiary of Alstom SA, the French train maker, was ordered to pay £16.4 million ($21.2 million) in a corruption case involving the supply of trams in Tunisia, the U.K.'s Serious Fraud Office said Monday.
